news.title: ‘Is Mnangagwa paying South African government for your healthcare?’— xenophobes taunt heavily pregnant Zimbabwean woman chased away from SA hospital
news.content:
By Staff Reporter

A HEAVILY pregnant Zimbabwean woman was recently publicly humiliated and chased away from Pretoria Wests Kalafong Hospital by a group of South African women, who insulted and accused her of burdening the countrys healthcare system.

South African authorities have, for long, expressed concern over the strain placed on public services by Zimbabwean nationals fleeing a collapsed healthcare system back home.

In the viral video, the unidentified Zimbabwean woman is seen being verbally attacked and told never to come back to the hospital by the women who said the Zimbabwean government does not pay the South African government for healthcare services.

We are talking to you, switch off the phone! You always come to South Africa to make babies why?

Wena, you come for blood tests for free, in our country? You know we pay tax? Is Mnangagwa paying the South African government for your healthcare? Mnangagwa is not paying us anything

Can you go and fix your problems with Mnangagwa, go to Zimbabwe, we do not want you here anymore.

Today, when you get home start making arrangements on where you are going to deliver that baby because here in Pretoria West you are not coming, we do not want you anymore! Go home!

The Zimbabwean woman tried to defend herself saying the group was ranting to the wrong person, which further infuriated them.

You can go to Ramaphosas house or Julius Malemas house. They will help you deliver this child.

You are using our facilities, so we are talking to the right person, it is you who came with a bag to give birth here in South Africa and you are nothing, you are not a South African, they added.

The pregnant womans viral video is not the first of such xenophobic attacks of Zimbabweans living across the Limpopo for allegedly straining South Africas healthcare system.

news.title: Man jailed 30 years for repeatedly raping daughter
news.content:
By Staff Reporter

REGIONAL Magistrate Letwin Rwodzi has sentenced a rogue father to 30 years in jail for raping his biological daughter on four occasions.

Magistrate Rwodzi said overwhelming evidence proved the mans guilt, emphasising that a fathers duty is to protect his children, not violate them.

The courts exist to safeguard minors and all vulnerable groups in society. A clear message must be sent that crime does not pay, said Rwodzi.

The accused was handed 15 years for the first two counts and another 15 years for the other two, resulting in an effective 30-year imprisonment.

Prosecutor Loveit Muringwa, proved that in April last year, the father returned home at Rainham Farm, Nyabira, Mashonaland West province and found his daughter seated on the floor.

He accused her of having an affair with her aunts husband while she stayed with them in Masvingo from Grade One to Seven.

After shouting at her, he lifted her onto a bed and raped her.

The court heard that in May, he raped her again, gave her pills, and warned her against speaking out. He repeated the assault in November, again providing morning-after pills to prevent pregnancy.

The victim confided in her mother the following day, but the mother initially dismissed the claims.

On March 16, 2025, the girl was raped once more at their home. She later followed her mother to an onion field, where she tearfully recounted the ordeal.

In a court affidavit, the mother admitted she had not reported the earlier incidents due to her husbands threats.

I was afraid of the threats, so I took no action. But on 16 March, around 4pm my daughter came to me crying that her father had raped her again. Disturbed, I called neighbours, who helped apprehend him.

The matter was then reported to the police, leading to the fathers arrest and subsequent conviction.

news.title: Harare woman in hot soup for facilitating rape of a 15-year-old girl
news.content:
By Staff Reporter

A HARARE woman has landed herself in serious trouble after she allegedly colluded with a local man to rape a 15-year-old girl, who was under her custody.

Lucious Sikadza appeared before Harare Regional Magistrate Marehwanazvo Gofa alongside her alleged accomplice, Shadreck Gaura, facing rape charges. The pair was advised to seek bail at the High Court.

According to the State, the victim had left her rural home, where she lived with her grandparents, and arrived in Harare on January 6, 2025. She spent the night in the central business district before approaching Sikadza the following day.

On January 7, 2025, the complainant told Sikadza that she had run away from home and needed a place to stay. Sikadza agreed and took her in, said prosecutor Lancelot Mutsokoti.

But the situation took a sinister turn on March 16, 2025, when Sikadza allegedly told the girl they would be sleeping at Gauras house in Kuwadzana 5.

The first accused (Sikadza) acted in connivance with the second accused (Gaura), who then took the complainant to his place and had sexual intercourse with her without her consent, Mutsokoti alleged.

The horrifying ordeal only came to light after the girls parents tracked her down and took her to the police. She was referred to hospital for medical examination, where she revealed the sexual abuse by Gaura.

Sikadza, who allegedly masterminded the whole ordeal, initially vanished but was later nabbed in Kuwadzana, leading to her arrest alongside Gaura.

The case continues as the accused prepare to fight for their freedom at the High Court.

news.title: After a 15-year dispute, UK’s Vast Resources finally gets its diamonds back, plans Zimbabwe comeback
news.content:
By newZWire

VAST Resources, a mining company listed on Londons AIM stock exchange, has finally received a long-awaited parcel of diamonds129,400 carats that had been held by the Reserve Bank of Zimbabwe since 2010.

This ends a long dispute with the government that began nearly two decades ago in 2006, when Vast Resources, then African Consolidated Resources, lost its mining rights in the Marange diamond fields. The government had revoked its claims, which were previously held by De Beers.

In 2010, during a legal battle over the rights, Vast had to surrender a large parcel of rough diamonds to RBZ.

For years, the diamonds sat in RBZs vaults as lawyers fought the case. A breakthrough came in 2023 when the High Court ordered the release of the diamonds. In 2024, the government approved a final settlement, allowing the parcel to be handed back to Vast.

In a statement on Friday, Vast said it has finally received the diamonds. The company says the diamond parcels have not been touched for over 15 years.

This release of the historical diamond parcel not only represents a landmark success for the company, but underlines that Zimbabwe is truly open for business for companies that wish to comply with due process, Vast says.

Although the exact value is not known yet, the company says early inspections have exceeded managements expectations. Once cleaned, the diamonds will be revalued and prepared for sale.

After the sale, about 20% of the total value will go towards feessuch as royalties, legal costs, marketing, and payments to the Minerals Marketing Corporation of Zimbabwe.

Vast previously owned the Pickstone and Eureka gold mines through Dallaglio, which it sold to Padenga Holdings in 2019 to focus on diamonds. In 2018, it partnered with Red Mercury, a local community trust in Marange-Zimunya, to explore new diamond areas, but legal issues stalled the project and Vast turned its focus elsewhere.

Now, with the dispute behind it, has Vast is looking to re-enter Zimbabwean mining.

CEO Andrew Prelea says: Now that this chapter has closed, the company is reengaging our future investment strategy in Zimbabwe and has commenced discussions for further mining concessions in-country.

Vast also has mining interests in Romania and Tajikistan.

news.title: ZiG monthly inflation rate up by 0,7%
news.content:
By Alois Vinga

THE local unit, Zimbabwe Gold (ZWG) suffered a 0,7 % inflation decline in the month of April 2025 with the greenback also depreciating slightly by 0,2%, the Zimbabwe National Statistics Agency (Zimstat) reported Friday.

Published data for the period shows the ZWG month-on-month inflation rate was 0, 6% in April 2025, gaining 0,7% on the March 2025 rate of -0.1 percent.The units year-on-year inflation rate (annual percentage change) for the month of April 2025 as measured by the all-items ZWG Consumer Price Index (CPI), was 85, 7%.

But market watchers believe the inflation rate fluctuations are still within the sustainable margins making them not a cause of fear in the markets.

The central bank has continued to maintain a tight grip on liquidity levels and just last week a major climb-down was announced by the government which saw general traders being allowed to set the official exchange rate under Statutory Instrument 34 of 2025. In the long term the move is expected to ease speculation and yield market discipline among players.

During the month of April 2025, Zimstat said the US$ month-on-month inflation rate was 0.2% in April 2025, gaining 0.1 percentage points on the March 2025 rate of 0.1 percent with year-on-year inflation rate (annual percentage change) for the month of April 2025 as measured by the all-items USD Consumer Price Index (CPI) standing at 14,4%.

The weighted month-on-month inflation rate was 0,3% in April 2025, gaining 0.3 percentage points on the March 2025 rate of 0.0 percent. The weighted year-on-year inflation rate (annual percentage change) for the month of April 2025 as measured by the all-items weighted Consumer Price Index (CPI), was 26.2 percent, said the stats agency.

The Food Poverty Line (FPL) for one person in April 2025 was ZWG 862.06. FPL represents the amount of money that an individual requires to afford a daily minimum energy intake of 2,100 calories.

The Total Consumption Poverty Line (TCPL) for one person was ZWG 1,263.41 in April 2025. The TCPL is the minimum amount of income an individual needs to afford both food and non-food items to meet their basic needs and avoid being classified as poor.

news.title: ​Crypto Meets Culture: How Young Zimbabweans Engage with Global Sports​ via Betting Platforms
news.content:
In Zimbabwe, where the local currency often feels like a game of chance itself (due to crazy high inflation), young people turn to a different kind of gamble  one that involves football, phones, and digital coins. Online sports betting, especially on crypto-friendly platforms, is more than just a quick entertainment. For many young Zimbabweans, its a way to stay connected to global sports and experiment with crypto.

Online betting in Zimbabwe isnt happening behind desktops  its all happening on phones. With more young people owning smartphones and mobile data becoming more accessible, placing a bet is often just a few taps away. In fact, mobile betting made up over70% of all sports wagersin Zimbabwe by 2025.

Apps like Betway Zimbabwe and Premier Bet Zimbabwe offer the best mobile experience  users can bet live, cash out early, and follow games right from their screens. That convenience has drawn in the 18 to 35yearold crowd, especially in cities, although rural users are catching up quickly.

Zimbabweans dont exactly have the most stable banking system to rely on. So its no surprise that crypto has caught on, especially in places where bank transfers are slow, expensive, or just not happening. Many Zimbabweans started buying cryptocurrencies when their economy struggled, and several waves ofhyperinflation(up to 785%) made the local currency essentially worthless. The economy improved, but the habit of crypto trading remained.

So, manyonline betting platformsnow accept Bitcoin, Ethereum, or other cryptocurrencies, making it easier to deposit and withdraw without a middleman slowing things down.

For some young people, on the contrary, betting is actually their first experience using crypto. From there, some start using digital money to save, trade, or even shop online. Its not just bettingits an introduction to a different way of handling money.

Moreover, crypto allows Zimbabweans to bet globally on major sports events, such as the FIFA World Cup and the NBA, among others. In fact, the betting industry in Zimbabwe has grown by 8.5% between 2023 and 2024 and continues to rise. Even though theres love for local football, its the big leagues that attract most attention. The English Premier League (EPL), National Basketball Association (NBA), and Ultimate Fighting Championship (UFC) are among the most popular choices. Its not just about placing betsits about following teams, staying up late for games, and knowing the stats better than the commentators on TV.

Betting adds more excitement, and it also connects Zimbabweans to global sports in real time. WhatsApp groups buzz with predictions, TikTok videos break down weekend fixtures, and when someone wins big, youll hear about it.

At the end of the day, online betting in Zimbabwe is about more than winning money. Its how young people connect with global culture and experiment with digital tools. Its not a perfect systemthere are risks, and the crypto side of it can be murky. But for a generation raised on mobile tech and global sports, its one of the few spaces where finance, fun, and fandom all come together.

news.title: Mablanyo takes blame for Dynamos’ poor run
news.content:
By Sports Reporter

Dynamos coach Lloyd Mablanyo Chigowe has taken the blame for his teams current poor run inthe ongoing campaign.

Dembare have lost three consecutive games and are currently sitting in position 10 on the log with 6 points.

Already, pressure is mounting for the Harare giants, who have won a single match this season, a one-nil win against Simba Bhora last month.

I try to take responsibility and shield the boys from pressure. What is happening is not ideal because it actually puts pressure on the technical team also.

Probably the senior players also have to take responsibility, but we have held our discussions as agroup and we all agreed that we have not done justice to the team, said Mablanyo.

Dynamos will be hoping to redeem themselves on Sunday when they face struggling KwekweUnited.

Although Kwekwe United seems to be a punching bag, Chigowe is worried about his strike force, which is failing to find the back of the net.

Dembare has only scored two goals in seven matches, a poor conversion rate which Mablanyobelieves needs to be worked on.

If you see the 1-0 margins we are losing, it shows you we have a crisis in front.

We are creating chances, and we are failing to convert.

One thing certain is we need to reinforce that area, but we are in a period where we cant register players and make amends.

news.title: Britain’s Lord Oates demands consequences for Zimbabwean govt over journalist Mhlanga’s continued detention
news.content:
By Leopold Munhende

INCARCERATED journalist Blessed Mhlangas situation was discussed on Thursday in Britains House of Lords, with outspoken Liberal Democrats peer Lord Jonny Oates demanding consequences for the Zimbabwean government.

Mhlanga has now spent 60 days in pretrial detention for daring to interview a war veteran, Blessed Geza, seeking President Emmerson Mnangagwas immediate ouster.

He was arrested after broadcasting the interview and accused of transmitting data messages that incite violence or damage to property.

Oates, who once resided in Zimbabwe, demanded that the UK government makes it clear to Mnangagwa and the Zanu PF government that normal relations between the former colonial power and Zimbabwe will not resume as long as basic rights such as those of the media were continuously disrespected.

As we speak, the journalistBlessedMhlangahas been detained for 59 days and denied his constitutional right to bail. His crime is having the temerity to conduct an interview with a former war veteran who opposes President Mnangagwas desire to extend his term in office and has highlighted the criminal corruption of the regime and the Presidents family, said Oates.

I hope the Government will continue to make clear that there will be no resumption of normal relations with Zimbabwe while the ZANU-PF regime continues to detain journalists, deny media freedom and defy democratic norms.

In a debate on media freedom in the House of Lords today, I raised the case of Zimbabwe journalist Blessed Mhlanga who has now been detained for 59 days for no other reason than reporting the truth.https://t.co/xjmYtz9Xf7

 Lord Jonny Oates (@jonny_oates)April 24, 2025

Zimbabwe and the UK have been in a cold-war since the early 2000s following a chaotic land redistribution programme that forcefully reclaimed landfrom white farmers and gave it to mainly Zanu PF members.

Disregard for human rights over the past two decades has also worsened the relations.

Mnangagwa, who is at the centre of the current mess, promised re-engagement upon taking office via a 2017 coup that toppled late President Robert Mugabe but the West has not cosied up to his endeavours.

Accused of grand corruption and shielding a circle of associates benefiting from Zimbabwes vast minerals, he now faces a faction from within his own party that wants him to resign and hand over power to his deputy, former ally and ex-army general Constantino Chiwenga.

Although known to also wield an iron fist, Chiwenga is seen as the solution to Zimbabwes worsening corruption, poor economy and extreme poverty in various communities.

Oates challenged Parliamentarians to bring the fight for Mhlangas freedom to Mnangagwas wife Auxillia who is set to speak at a summit in London in June.

Added Oates: I note that the Presidents wife is due to speak at a summit in London in June.

I hope that Members of our Parliament who are choosing to take part will challenge Zimbabwes First Lady on the continued detention ofBlessedMhlangaand the overall brutality of the regime she represents.

Mhlanga is a senior journalist at privately owned Alpha Media Holdings (AMH) and also hosts shows for its Heart and Soul TV.

news.title: Tobacco bales sold so far down by 16%
news.content:
By Alois Vinga

THE quantity of tobacco sold so far has gone down by 16% when compared to the same period last year on the back of waning average prices, a trading update by the Tobacco Industry Marketing Board (TIMB) has revealed.

This years tobacco marketing season kicked off in March 2025 on the back of expectations of better yields in the current selling season.

Market data shows that bales sold so far totalled 1,148,330 compared to 1,379,535, signifying a minus 16,76% decline compared to the same period last year. On day 34, a total of 93,9 million kgs of tobacco was sold compared to 105 816 289 signifying a minus 11,8% decline.

The average price reached this year was US$3,42 per kg compared to US$3,58 per kg to signify a decrease of 4,57%. Rejected bales stood at 3,04% compared to 2,34%. The highest price fetched so far is standing at US$6,30 compared to US$6,99 to record a minus 9,87%

The continents top tobacco producer expects sales of the crop to rebound to 280 million kilograms this year after plummeting to 230.9 million kilograms in 2024 following an El Nino-induced drought.

Despite lower production in 2024, tobacco was the second biggest export commodity for Zimbabwe last year, only behind gold, earning a record $1.3 billion.

The projected 2025 sales are still below the record high of 296 million kilograms registered in 2023.

Over 80% of Zimbabwes tobacco is produced by small farmers.

The new season opened with prices ranging from US$1,59 per kilogram for the lowest tobacco grade to US$4,65 per kilogram for the highest.

news.title: Border official jailed for smuggling 96 tonnes of chrome
news.content:
By Staff Reporter

A CUSTOMER services agent at Beitbridge Border Post was recently dragged to court for facilitating the illegal passage into South Africa of three haulage trucks loaded with a combined 96 tonnes of chrome.

Accused person, Brian Zimbume, a customer service agent at Andalusia Investments Pvt Limited, trading as ZimBorders, was convicted of two counts of fraud and sentenced to 18 months imprisonment.

On his court appearance, Zimbume faced fraud charges, or violating provisions of the Customs and Excise Act for smuggling chrome shipments, potentially prejudicing the Zimbabwe Revenue Authority (ZIMRA) of income.

Agreed facts were that in September 2024, offender deceived ZIMRA officials into giving him access to their scanning tablets under false pretences, claiming he wanted to fix system or network issues.

Instead,the offender used the devices to illegally approve the release of three Scania haulage trucks carrying a total of 96 tonnes of chrome concentrate into South Africa without proper clearance.
